topics.title: Why storytelling matters in business communication
topics.summary: Matthew explains that business people fear standing out, but without stories they become forgettable. He argues our minds retain imagery and narrative, not charts, stats, or platitudes.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Matthew Dicks, his storytelling credentials (The Moth wins), and what the episode will cover: tactical storytelling, stage comfort, finding story ideas, and the “five-second moment.”

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for OneSchema (CSV importing) and Maui Nui Venison (wild-harvested venison), including listener discounts.

topics.title: Matthew’s approach: teaching meets storytelling
topics.summary: Lenny and Matthew discuss why Storyworthy is so actionable and how Matthew’s 25 years as a teacher shapes his practical storytelling instruction.

topics.title: The five-second moment: transformation or realization
topics.summary: Matthew lays out his core thesis: every good story centers on a single moment of change (transformation/realization), with the rest serving as context to make that moment vivid for the audience.

topics.title: Examples: Eileen in class and Star Wars
topics.summary: Matthew illustrates the “moment of change” with a classroom story about a student’s confidence and a pop-culture example where Luke Skywalker shifts from tech to faith in The Force.

topics.title: Start at the end: opposites define story shape
topics.summary: They discuss how knowing the ending (the change) determines the beginning as its opposite, why predictable endings don’t ruin stories, and why “reporting” events chronologically fails.

topics.title: Why change creates universal connection
topics.summary: Matthew explains that change is what makes stories relatable beyond shared context; audiences connect to emotional transformation even if they don’t share the storyteller’s situation.

topics.title: The dinner test and telling your own story
topics.summary: Matthew introduces the “dinner test” (tell stories naturally, not with gimmicky openings) and argues stories must be centered on the teller to enable vulnerability; he shares a Holocaust-descendants example.

topics.title: Why vacation stories fail and where to start
topics.summary: They cover why most vacation stories are boring, how to cut to the meaningful moment, and the principle of starting as close to the end as possible (bear-eating-the-tent / Vonnegut).

topics.title: Stakes: keeping audiences wondering what’s next
topics.summary: Matthew defines stakes as the audience’s worry/curiosity and shares techniques to create them (elephant, backpack, breadcrumbs, hourglass, crystal ball), plus how surprise should feel inevitable yet unexpected.

topics.title: Stakes in practice: Charity Thief and pacing
topics.summary: Matthew points to his story “Charity Thief” as an example of layering stakes when little happens plot-wise, contrasts with inherently high-stakes premises, and warns against front-loading all stakes.

topics.title: Business impact: being remembered versus forgotten
topics.summary: Matthew argues that without stories, business communication becomes bland and forgettable; he contrasts a memorable lunchbox story at a conference with an executive talk that was instantly forgotten.

topics.title: Applying storytelling at work: Boris and Marsha
topics.summary: Matthew shares concrete workplace applications: a factory owner uses a Little League failure story to coach sales resilience (building “bricks” vs “band-aids”), and a Slack comms leader adds a personal origin anecdote to strengthen a competitive narrative.
